image.altText: Anonymous woman lies in a bed with heart rate monitor clipped on finger at the Marie Stopes clinic in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: A bill from Liberal MP Ben Hood, which if successful would require women seeking to terminate a pregnancy from 28 weeks to instead undergo an induced birth, has prompted intense debate.

title.children: A proposed change to SA's abortion law been described as 'extreme right-wing'. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A large seal in water on its back yawning

props.synopsis: Sammy the elephant seal weighs thousands of kilograms and normally lives near Antarctica. But Portland locals have embraced him, while avoiding some of the trouble Tasmanians have experienced with another of his kind.

title.children: Victorian town falls in love with Sammy the four-tonne elephant seal

image.altText: Australian flag on a pole outside the Melbourne Shrine of Remembrance

props.synopsis: The City of Unley reverses its decision to hold Australia Day citizenship and awards ceremonies on January 25 after the council conducted a survey that found a majority of residents supported celebrating the events on the public holiday.

title.children: Council reverses its decision to move Australia Day events away from public holiday

image.altText: Portrait photo of suspected murder victim Phyllis Harrison.

props.synopsis: A man accused of killing three people over 13 years allegedly had a "thing" for knives and told two people he had stabbed an "old lady", a court has heard.

title.children: Former prison mate tells court alleged serial killer 'stabbed' woman and threw knife in bushes

image.altText: Green and red table grapes from the United States, $19.99 and $21.99 per kilo.

props.synopsis: If you have baulked at the price of table grapes at the supermarket lately the good news is they could drop by up to $10/kg when the Australian season brings locally-grown produce to the shelves.

title.children: Eyewatering supermarket grape prices expected to drop dramatically as local season approaches

image.altText: An SA Police vehicle with flashing lights.

props.synopsis: SA Police charges a 20-year-old disability worker with dangerous driving following a fatal crash at Hayborough, south of Adelaide on Sunday that killed a woman using a wheelchair.

title.children: Disability worker charged after fatal crash south of Adelaide

image.altText: Close up of sign saying Unley Oval

props.synopsis: The City of Unley announces findings from a public survey about a controversial fence that has created division in an inner-south community of Adelaide.

title.children: Council to create concept design for Unley Oval fence but maintains no decision has been made

image.altText: A close up of a black and white dairy cow

props.synopsis: About 22 farmers and 159 workers at the company's Jervois and Murray Bridge sites will be affected by the development.

title.children: SA dairy Beston Global Food Company goes into voluntary administration

image.altText: Smoke billows over southern Lebanon

props.synopsis: After almost a year of war against Hamas in Gaza on its southern border, Israel is shifting its focus to its northern frontier.

title.children: Israel and Hezbollah exchange fire after Lebanon suffers huge casualties

image.altText: Joe Biden stands in front of a green wall and holds up a hand.

props.synopsis: World leaders are gathering in New York this week with a growing list of conflicts and crises to discuss. Here are some takeaways from the first day of debate at the UN General Assembly.

title.children: Warned of a 'powder keg that risks engulfing the world', global leaders gather at the UN

image.altText: Portraits of nine women looking serious are arranged in a grid.

props.synopsis: Thousands of Australian women who won a landmark class action settlement more than a year ago over damage done by pelvic mesh have still not received any compensation.

title.children: Women in pelvic mesh class action feel 'ripped off' by legal process

image.altText: A woman with short brown hair and glasses speaks in front of a media wall that says "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: Figures released on Wednesday are likely to show inflation is extraordinarily low. They will only add to the pressure on the Reserve Bank governor to cut rates.

title.children: The RBA governor has defended not cutting rates. But there's a problem with what she said

image.altText: A woman holding a young child.

props.synopsis: Medicare is now covering just over half of specialist fees, forcing Australians to increasingly dip into their own pockets and delay vital care.

title.children: Experts warn Medicare rebates for specialists 'almost meaningless'

image.altText: A crowd of out-of-focus people walk in front of a large in-focus Coles supermarket sign.

props.synopsis: You can't have missed the parade of political figures this year lining up to take a kick at the nation's biggest supermarket chains, Coles and Woolworths, who jointly control about 65 per cent of the grocery market.

title.children: It's a good ol' fashioned game of 'stacks on' for Coles and Woolworths

image.altText: A handful of uniform soldiers stand on top of two military tanks in bushland

props.synopsis: Twelve injured Singaporean servicemen are airlifted by military helicopter to Rockhampton Hospital, after a collision during Exercise Wallaby at training area at Shoalwater Bay.

title.children: Two armoured vehicles collide during major international military training exercise in Central Queensland

image.altText: An electric vehicle by Geely is seen displayed at a car showroom.

props.synopsis: The federal government says it is in contact with the US about the new moves it has put up against Chinese car companies.

title.children: The US government is effectively banning Chinese-made cars from its roads. Some in Australia want the government to take notice

image.altText: Suzanne Armstrong and Susan Bartlett were housemates in Collingwood in 1977.

props.synopsis: Over the weekend Perry Kouroumblis was arrested in Rome in connection to the 1977 Easey Street murders. It was news that left his friend Phil Akers 'dumbfounded'.

title.children: Friend 'dumbfounded' by arrest of Perry Kouroumblis over Easey Street murders

image.altText: An elaborate Chinese dragon in bright colours being paraded on a street, a few dragon carriers visible around it

props.synopsis: Two of Bendigo's Golden Dragons were vandalised earlier this year. In the wake of the heartbreak, we tell the remarkable story of how the third dragon came to be.

title.children: How lions, vandalism and Richard Branson led to the world's largest Golden Dragon in regional Victoria

image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Police have renewed their search in the case of missing Ballarat woman Samantha Murphy, with efforts set to continue on Wednesday.

title.children: Police launch fresh search in case of missing Ballarat woman Samantha Murphy

image.altText: A weather map of Australia showing temperature changes for the week

props.synopsis: While parts of Australia's east coast are forecast for warm weather, a cold polar air mass is expected to bring rain and temperature declines of up to 20 degrees Celsius across the continent's south-east before the end of the week.

title.children: Icy change to bring 24-hour temperature drop of up to 20C as widespread rain soaks Australia

image.altText: A woman with braided red hair kneels and embraces a young boy with blonde hair who looks upset.

props.synopsis: The rate of psychiatric medication prescribed to Australian children and teenagers has more than doubled in the past 10 years, according to new government data.

title.children: Antidepressants, antipsychotics and stimulants up: Why are children taking more mental health medications?

image.altText: A man holds a large knife and looks at the camera with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: Teenagers in England and Wales are twice as likely to be killed by a knife now than they were 10 years ago and as violent knife crime continues to rise the UK takes measures like a buy-back scheme similar to Australia's after the Port Arthur massacre.

title.children: UK authorities want these 'zombie knives' off the streets and they're hoping something borrowed from Australia will help

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is set to open higher after Wall Street hit new record highs overnight. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to edge higher after Wall Street hits new record highs

image.altText: The broken shell of a caravan upside down on a wet road

props.synopsis: Road safety groups and travellers say training for drivers towing large vehicles — and even a special licence — should be implemented across Australia.

title.children: Travellers back calls for mandatory motorhome and caravan driver training

image.altText: Man in red glasses and blue shirt

props.synopsis: A former competition watchdog chief says the "power of the business lobby" has stymied a key reform to deter supermarket price gouging.

title.children: Former regulator says 'business lobby' shielding supermarkets from reform

image.altText: Rubbish at the site, viewed through a wire fence.

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation has found the 180-hectare property on the Fraser Coast, marketed as part of an "eco-development", has become an alleged pollution time bomb, after being used to illegally dump more than 35,000 tonnes of waste.

title.children: Former Bandido bikie associate left to contain massive alleged illegal toxic waste dump

image.altText: Anonymous woman lies in a bed with heart rate monitor clipped on finger at the Marie Stopes clinic in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: A bill from Liberal MP Ben Hood, which if successful would require women seeking to terminate a pregnancy from 28 weeks to instead undergo an induced birth, has prompted intense debate.

title.children: A proposed change to SA's abortion law been described as 'extreme right-wing'. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: a woman in a white suit in the House of Reps smiling

props.synopsis: The federal government says the extensions will secure the jobs of more than 1,800 workers, but the move has angered environmentalists who have described the decision as "the opposite of climate action".

title.children: Three NSW coal mines to be extended for another 30 to 40 years after federal government approval

image.altText: Palmer pic

props.synopsis: The federal government is close to announcing an electoral reform proposal likely to provoke teal independents and trigger a legal challenge from Clive Palmer.

title.children: Government sets crosshairs on 'billionaire' political donors, including teal backers

image.altText: A sign sits outside Launceston General Hospital.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's Health Department will appoint a senior doctor to conduct audits of patient death records across the health system from before 2019. It follows a report in June which found 29 deaths were never referred to the coroner when they should have been.

title.children: 'We haven't got this right': Tasmania to appoint senior doctor to audit patient death records

image.altText: a woman's face in shadow

props.synopsis: When Emma's high-school aged daughter told her about being physically attacked by a group of her peers, she felt heartbroken. It's just one example of bullying behaviour that is on the rise in ACT schools.

title.children: A graphic video of a child being violently attacked was circulated online – it ended up with her mother

image.altText: Black outline of woman with arms pressed up against the corner of two walls, against a pink background.

props.synopsis: For the thousands of Australians caring for dependant kids and sick parents, the impact on their physical and mental health is significant. So what can be done about it?

title.children: When you're a carer, self-preservation 'shouldn't be mistaken as selfishness'. Here's how to look after yourself
